This is a great test for your model because it is highly ambiguous. Itâ€™s short, polite, and doesn't contain any obvious "spam" keywords. However, itâ€™s a standard response used by support teams every day.  Here is how a legitimate company (let's use a FinTech company as an example) would respond to a customer asking for clarification.  The Legitimate Customer Support Response Subject: Follow-up regarding your inquiry (Ticket #44921)  Dear [Customer Name],  Thank you for reaching out to the FinTrack Support Team.  To clarify, the previous notification was regarding the updated Terms of Service for our international wire transfers, which will take effect on March 1st. We sent this to ensure all our users are aware of the new fee structure for cross-border transactions.  You don't need to take any action unless you disagree with the new terms. You can view the full document on our official website at: https://www.fintrack.com/legal/terms-2026  If you have specific questions about how this affects your account balance, please feel free to reply to this email or visit our Help Center.  Best regards,  Ananya R. > Senior Support Specialist | FinTrack Inc.  Your security is our priority. We will never ask for your password or OTP via email.

Hi, could you please clarify what this is about? I want to make sure I understand before I proceed.

Hi Suraj,  Thank you for contacting GitHub Support.  This automated alert was sent because a new Personal Access Token (PAT) was generated for your account. These tokens are used as an alternative to passwords when authenticating with GitHub via the command line or third-party applications (like VS Code).  If you recently set up GitHub on a new computer or integrated a new coding environment, this token was likely created during that process. You can review, manage, or delete all active tokens at any time by logging into your account and navigating to: Settings > Developer settings > Personal access tokens  For more information on how tokens work, you can visit our official documentation here: https://docs.github.com/en/authentication  If you still do not recognize this activity, we recommend revoking the token immediately and changing your account password.  Best regards, The GitHub Support Team
